title: VFX in The Umbrella Academy
credit_line:
VFX Supervisor: Chris White
Courtesy Weta Digital and Netflix
brief_description: A look at how Weta Digital made Pogo in The Umbrella Academy.

constellations_primary.name: MoCaps and rotos
constellations_primary.description: Though VFX continues to push boundaries and brings fantastical worlds and creatures to life, there's still a place for classic animation techniques.

description: “Nietzsche once said ‘Man is as a rope stretched between the animal and the superhuman’,” muses Sir Reginald Hargreeves in the first episode of Umbrella Academy (2019). It’s an ironic line, given the most human character in the Netflix original series is not human at all, but rather a being who personifies the middle ground between the animal and the superhuman. There are few places better suited to delicately walking that line than Weta Digital, with the New Zealand-based digital visual effects company creating the character of Pogo. Think Batman’s butler but, well, a chimpanzee. Guardian to the dysfunctional Hargreeves family of superheroes, actor Ken Hall’s movements on set became a visual reference for Weta animators, combined with the facial and vocal performance of Adam Godley in the studio.
description_for_label: “Nietzsche once said ‘Man is as a rope stretched between the animal and the superhuman’,” muses Sir Reginald Hargreeves in the Umbrella Academy. It’s ironic, given the most human character in the show isn’t human but a being who bridges the animal and the superhuman. New Zealand-based VFX studio Weta Digital drew on past experience rendering CGI apes to bring Pogo to life. Think Batman’s butler but a chimpanzee, which Weta made by combining Ken Hall’s on-set movements and Adam Godley’s facial and vocal performance.
